block.p: Negotiations aimed at producing a budget based on an income tax broke down last night amid disagreement over how big the new tax should be.

The breakdown marked another failed effort to end Connecticut's 32-day-old budget impasse, which threatens to last through the weekend, raising the possibility of another partial shutdown of state government next week.
Negotiations aimed at producing a budget based on an income tax broke down last night amid disagreement over how big the new tax should be.

The breakdown marked another failed effort to end Connecticut's 32-day-old budget impasse, which threatens to last through the weekend, raising the possibility of another partial shutdown of state government next week.
"This effort has broken down," said Senator George Jepsen, Democrat of Stamford.
Republicans, who were expected to contribute three votes toward the 18 needed to pass an income tax in the Senate, said they could provide only two votes for a broad-based income tax.

"The endeavor over the last 36 hours has not at this point succeeded," said Senator William Nickerson, Republican of Greenwich. Mr. Nickerson said he doubted that the Legislature could negotiate a new budget and pass it by Sunday, when the current seven-day budget expires.
Without agreement by Sunday, the Legislature will be forced to rush through another continuing resolution and hope that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. will sign it.
A key supporter of a state income tax, Rep. Richard Mulready, said the budget talks will now likely shift back to the legislative leaders who oppose an income tax. (AP) METRO DATELINES
